Module 2 Accessing ForestPlots What is ForestPlots? How to access ForestPlots data?

Module 2 Accessing ForestPlots When re-censusing a plot, you need access to the data from the previous censuses in order to make a field sheet, find the plot, and collect the data. You can find everything you need on ForestPlots.net.   What is ForestPlots? ForestPlots.net is a database where you can securely store, manage and analyse tropical forest plot data.   ForestPlots.net stores and serves stem data and metadata for multi- and single-census plots in forests and savannas, including trees, lianas, species, demography, traits and soils. How to access ForestPlots data? In order to access the ForestPlots data, you must Read the code of conduct, Register to have an account on ForestPlots here, and Email the associated country data officer to ensure the account is granted and to receive the necessary training to use ForestPlots. Note: Nika Gorski is the data officer for Africa data. Only once you have completed these steps will you be able to access data to ForestPlots and produce field sheets. If you haven’t fully completed these steps, you can still move on to Module 3 and 4 to install the necessary software on your laptop and tablet.

Module 4 How to set up your tablet Excel QGIS
Module 4 How to set up your tablet Eliott to explain how to make sure the tablet is set up with QGIS, a passcode, etc. Excel QGIS

Module 5 Tablet to Laptop (Vice Versa) Learning objectives Move documents from your laptop onto your tablet Move documents from your tablet onto your laptop   One of the most important steps for collecting data digitally is to be able to access your data. So before diving in to collect data and create a QField project, let’s learn how to move documents between your two devices. 1. Create a folder on your computer called QGIS_training, and save this folder somewhere that you know how to get to and will navigate to often. 2. Save this a picture of a very common tree in the Republic of Congo into your QGIS_training folder: moabi_tree.png. Do you know what kind of tree it is? 3. Connect your tablet to your computer via the cable. 4. In your files on the bottom left of your screen, you will see a new device appear. For example, in the image below when an Apple iPad was plugged into the device, it appeared.   5. Copy your QGIS_training folder. 6. Paste your QGIS_training folder into the tablet area of your device. 7. Disconnect your tablet from your computer. Is the image on your tablet? 8. This time download a pdf document and save it to your computer and move it to the tablet: ForestPlot Codes. When you are done, disconnect the tablet from the laptop and check that the pdf is on your tablet. 9. Now to move a document from the tablet to your computer, you do the same thing but in reverse. With your tablet disconnected from your computer, take a photo of your neighbor (with their permission) and save it to your QGIS_training folder with their name. 10. Connect your laptop and tablet via the cable and move the image from the tablet’s QGIS_training folder into the QGIS_training folder on your laptop. 11 Disconnect your laptop and tablet. On your computer do you have an image of a tree, a pdf, and an image of your neighbor in your QGIS_training folder? And that’s how to move documents between your laptop and tablet.

Module 10 QGIS practice - plot XYZ Learning objectives Practice what you’ve learned   The only way to master a skill is to practice. So let’s practice. insert name has requested that all field teams collect data for a new research project. It is your job to successfully collect this data and send it to the insert cool group for them to upload the data to the database and analyse it. 1. On a piece of paper, write down the steps you will take from retrieving the data all the way through sending your collected data to your colleague. Show to one of the instructors before moving on 2. The plot that you will be working with has previously been re-censused. You can see a plot dump of the data here (insert attached excel document). Based on the information, why will we collect this data via QGIS? Hint: why did we have to collect data in Module 8 in Excel? 3. Create a folder called XYZ_plot_practice in your QGIS_training folder. 4. Here is the geopackage that you will need to generate the QGIS survey. Save this file in your XYZ_plot_practice folder. 5. Create a QGIS package called XYZ_collection. 6. Transfer the XYZ_data_collection package to your tablet and collect the data. 7. Transfer your collected data back onto your laptop into your XYZ_plot_practice folder so that you have your original XYZ_data_collection package, your collected data in a file called XYZ_data_collected, and your newly collected data called XYZ_complete.xlsx. 8. Review the XYZ_complete excel file. Do you notice any errors? What post-processing will you have to do? 9. Now that you have the data on your computer, what would you do next? 10. Show your XYZ_complete file to your instructor and show them your answer to number 9.

Module 13 Collecting data via Excel Learning Objectives Understand how to collect ForestPlots data using Excel on a tablet Set up your computer In order to collect data on your tablet via excel, you need two things: To stay organised and Excel Hopefully, you have already configured this in Module 2 and 3. If you have not set up your devices, return to the section Setting up your devices. If you already have Excel on your tablet and laptop, then let’s get ready to collect some data. Upload the excel sheet to the tablet In the field we refer to the physical sheet of paper that we collect data on as the field sheet. For the sake of this course, we are going to refer to the physical field sheet as a field sheet. However, when we collect data with excel, we will call this an Excel sheet (just to help differentiate the field sheet types - this will make more sense later on). (ELIOTT insert instructions) Collect data on the tablet (ELIOTT insert instructions) Transfer data to a computer (ELIOTT insert instructions)   Exercise 1. Create a folder for the course called QGIS_training. 2. Download the pre-prepared excel sheet on your laptop (insert link to the excel file here later - need to decide if this will be a correctly locked field sheet or just a regular field sheet with no locking). 3. What do you notice about the excel sheet? Can you type in all of the columns? Is it easy to read? 4 Move the excel sheet from your laptop onto your tablet. 5. Disconnect the laptop and the tablet and fill in the excel sheet. 6. Save the filled in field excel on your computer. Discussion: How was the experience? What potential errors can you see?
Module 14 Preparing Excel field sheets Preparing field sheets on ForestPlots Preparing excel sheets for the tablet Exercise

Module 14 Preparing Excel field sheets Learning objectives Review how to create a field sheet on ForestPlots. Learn how to lock columns. Practice collecting data on an Excel field sheet.   Preparing field sheets on ForestPlots If you already know how to prepare field sheets through the ForestPlots database, skip ahead to the next section. If you need a refresher on how to create field sheets, watch this video or visit page 174 of the ForestPlots Manual. If you’ve never been shown how to make field sheets before by a ForestPlots team member, reach out to the data officer of the country that you will be collecting data in and request training (see Module 2). Preparing excel sheets for the tablet Preparing excel sheets to collect data on a tablet is very similar to preparing regular field sheets. In fact, the first step is the same: - download a field sheet from ForestPlots, - and format the field sheet to only see the columns that you want to work with. The next step is slightly different. Rather than set your print area, now you are going to lock columns that you do not want to accidentally modify in the field. (ELIOTT insert instructions and necessary images to show how to lock columns)   Exercise In your group create your own locked excel field sheet and decide which columns you believe are required for field work. Discussion: Compare group field sheets. What are the similarities and the differences among field sheets?

Module 16 Excel practice - plot ABC Learning objectives Practice what you’ve learned   The only way to master a skill is to practice. So let’s practice. insert name has requested that all field teams collect data for a new research project. It is your job to successfully collect this data and send it to the insert cool group for them to upload the data to the database and analyse it. 1. On a piece of paper, write down the steps you will take to, firstly, get the data on your device and lastly, send your collected data to your colleague. Show to one of the instructors before moving on 2. The plot that you will be working with has previously been re-censused. You can see a plot dump of the data here (insert attached excel document). Why is it that we would decide to collect this data via and Excel sheet and not QGIS? Hint: What information is not very thorough within this plot dump? 3. Create a folder called ABC_plot_practice in your QGIS_training folder. 4. Someone from the ForestPlots team has very kindly downloaded a ForestPlots field sheet for you (aren’t they amazing). Save this file in your ABC_plot_practice folder. 5. Create a locked Excel file following the guidelines that we discussed in Module 6 and call it ABC_excel_sheet. 6. Transfer the ABC_data_collection to your tablet and collect the data. 7. Transfer your collected data back onto your laptop into your ABC_plot_practice folder so that you have your original ABC_data_collection file and your newly collected data called ABC_complete. 8. Review the ABC_complete file. Do you notice any errors? What post-processing will you have to do? 9. Make a copy of the ABC_complete excel sheet and name it ABC_for_upload. Make any edits that you need to based on your revision. 10. Now it’s time to celebrate! You just collected data via a tablet. Let’s come together as a group and talk about the process.
